Award.AwardTitle: USF Robert Noyce STEM Scholars Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The University of South Florida Robert Noyce Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Scholar program prepares STEM professionals, both change-of-career and recent graduates, to teach secondary school mathematics or science in one of the following high needs county-wide school districts in the Tampa Bay area: Hernando, Highlands, Hillsborough, Manatee, Pasco, Pinellas, Polk, or Sarasota. Thirty-one Noyce Scholars are participating in a year long Master of Arts in Teaching program designed to prepare them to effectively teach culturally, linguistically, and socio-economically diverse learners. They are participating in a common core of education courses and disciplinary-specific pedagogical courses designed to help them translate their subject matter knowledge into effective practices for teaching and encouraging students in grades 6 - 12 to excel in the areas of mathematics or the sciences. The program offers both course related and non-course related experiences to engage these scholars in a professional learning community and to provide ongoing support throughout the program and during their first two years as classroom teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of South Florida (USF) Robert Noyce Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Scholar program addressed the supply shortage in mathematics and science by increasing the number of individuals who complete the a state-approved MAT initial certification program in mathematics and science (biology, chemistry, earth/space science, and physics) at the secondary level (grades 6-12). The program provided stipends of $30,000 to 31 STEM professionals (23 science and 8 mathematics) to enable them to earn their teaching credentials in mathematics and science. 

The Program has now produced 29 teachers, with 2 more expected by May 2018.  These scholars were responsible for over 3000 students during the 2016-17 academic year, and will be for each subsequent year if they remain in teaching. Based on scholar reporting from the end of the 2016-17 academic year, most program completers are expected to continue to teach in Title I districts, in furtherance of the goals of the Noyce STEM Scholars program. Noyce scholars have forged relationship between and among participants from different cohorts; program completers in early cohorts are working with the last cohort of scholars. Additionally, scholars have committed to work with STEM education majors at USF beyond the funding period.  

The program was successful in achieving its goals to recruit, retain, and support Robert A. Noyce STEM Scholars as teachers in high needs schools. The almost unanimous belief of program participants that their own teacher preparation far exceeded that of their teaching colleagues who were alternatively certified through other avenues is strong indication of the success of this program at USF.

Additionally, scholars have committed to work with STEM education majors at USF beyond the funding period. The program was successful in achieving its goals to recruit, retain, and support Robert A.
